section.name: Overview
section.p: Vulcan requires some Java components to be installed on your machine before Vulcan itself can be installed. There are many options which can satisfy these dependencies, and this document refers to the most common or likely choices.

section.name: Java Runtime Environment
section.p: First, you will need a Java Runtime Environment, version 5.0 or later. If you already have either the JDK or JRE installed, skip to the next section.
Download the JRE from Sun Microsystems at http://java.sun.com.

p.span: Note: It is not necessary to install the web browser integration when installing the JRE.

section.p: When you install the JRE, make a note of where it was installed, since you may need to reference this location when installing Apache Tomcat.

section.name: Web Application Server
section.p: Vulcan requires a JEE 1.4 compliant Web Application Server. The best open source option is to use Apache Tomcat 5.5 or later, available from http://tomcat.apache.org. When following the setup, make sure that the JRE you installed in the previous section is selected for use with Tomcat.

If you are installing on Microsoft Windows, you will have the option to install Apache Tomcat as a Windows Service. This is recommended because it will allow Apache Tomcat to automatically start when the computer boots.

section.name: Download Vulcan
section.p: Use the download link in the left-hand menu to download the latest stable version of Vulcan.

section.name: Unpack Vulcan
section.p: Although you can take the the WAR file you downloaded and deploy it directly, it is recommended that you unpack the WAR file so you can apply configuration settings before you install Vulcan.
The file you downloaded (vulcan.war) is really just a ZIP file with a different extension. You can unpack it using any software that supports the ZIP format.

In Microsoft Windows, you may need to rename vulcan.war to vulcan.zip so programs will recognize it. Afterwards, you should be able to open the archive using either Windows Explorer (using the Compressed Folder capability) or in WinZip.
In Linux and other operating systems, you can simply use the "unzip" command to extract the files.

p.span: Note: Make sure to create a new folder to use when unpacking Vulcan, because the archive itself does not create a subdirectory.

section.name: Vulcan Pre-deployment Steps
section.p: Vulcan comes configured with default settings which you may wish to customize. Some of these settings should be applied before you deploy Vulcan. If you plan to enable security, which is recommended, or if you would like Vulcan to store its configuration files somewhere other than the default location, you will have to modify files in the Vulcan WAR (Web Application Archive) before deployment.
Read the Security Configuration and Advanced Customization sections now, before deploying Vulcan.

section.name: Deploy Vulcan
section.p: At this point you should have the JRE installed, Apache Tomcat installed and running, and Vulcan configured for your security needs. Now it is time to deploy Vulcan.

You will be using the Apache Tomcat Manager application to deploy Vulcan. However, for security reasons, Apache Tomcat must be configured before you can access this application. See the Apache Tomcat Manager Howto for instructions on how to do this.
Access the Apache Tomcat Manager application by directing a web browser to http://localhost:8080/manager/html.
After you log in, find the text box labelled WAR or Directory URL and enter the directory where you unpacked Vulcan.
If you would like Vulcan to reside at the root of your Tomcat server, enter / in the text box labelled Context Path. Otherwise, enter /vulcan.
Click the Deploy button. When the page refreshes, you should see Vulcan in the list of applications. Click the link to navigate over to Vulcan.
